ground_truth: Delmar whistles appreciatively and lurches threateningly to his feet as Everett scrambles up, watching the white-robed people following in the wake of the tenor. There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods, all of them strangely oblivious to the three men. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground, the background, and the campsite itself. We are booming down to reveal a minister in the foreground who stands belly-deep in the river, easing a white-robed man back-down into the water. Behind him, a line of robed singers lengthens steadily as people stream out of the woods. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as white-robed people continue to drift past them. Delmar wades out into the stream, cutting in line, and reaches the minister, holding his nose as the minister incantates over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby, a smoldering twig fire burns while a bloodhound on a leash circles into frame, its tail fiercely wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Everett drives, shaking his head with a forebearing smile, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both dripping wet. He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish black man in worn go-to-meetin' clothes stands on the shoulder, waggling his thumb at the passing car. The man grabs his battered guitar case as the car pulls over and trots up to the open window. Everett looks at the man in the rearview mirror as he pulls out, and Tommy shrugs, causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he studies the man. The car pulls into the parking lot of a single-story cement-block building with a hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men get out of the car, Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and holds a white cane. Everett grimaces, thinking, as the three singing convicts form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who plays his guitar into a can microphone, performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize cars pulls into the lot, and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door, whooping it up. A sixty-year-old man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car, as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him. A big shambling man of about thirty follows him out of the car.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Delmar hums appreciatively and lurches menacingly to his feet as Everett scrambles up, observing the white-clad people trailing in the wake of the tenor. There are increasingly more white garments drifting through the forest, all of them oddly unaware of the three males. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground, the background, and the campsite itself. We are booming down to disclose a clergy in the foreground who stands belly-deep in the river, lowering a white-robed male back-down into the water. Behind him, a queue of robed vocalists lengthens steadily as people stream out of the forest. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the forest and gaze down at the river as white-clad people continue to drift past them. Delmar wades out into the stream, cutting in line, and reaches the clergy, holding his nose as the clergy intones over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby, a smoldering branch fire burns while a bloodhound on a leash circles into frame, its tail vigorously wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Everett drives, shaking his head with a tolerant smile, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both dripping wet. He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish black male in worn formal clothes stands on the shoulder, waggling his thumb at the passing vehicle. The male grabs his battered guitar case as the vehicle pulls over and trots up to the open window. Everett glances at the male in the rearview mirror as he pulls out, and Tommy shrugs, causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he examines the male. The vehicle pulls into the parking lot of a single-story cement-block edifice with a hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the males get out of the vehicle, Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged male who wears dark spectacles and holds a white cane. Everett grimaces, pondering, as the three vocalizing prisoners form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who strums his guitar into a can microphone, performing a hot and harmonized rendition of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize vehicles pulls into the lot, and Tommy and the three prisoners burst out of the station door, whooping it up. A sixty-year-old male in massive seersucker trousers held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a burgeoning belly exits from the first vehicle, as Delmar waves a fistful of cash at him. A big shambling male of about thirty follows him out of the vehicle.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Delmar's appreciative whistle is followed by his threatening lurch to his feet as Everett scrambles up, watching the white-robed people who are following in the wake of the tenor. More and more white robes are drifting through the woods, with all of them strangely oblivious to the three men. The foreground, the background, and the campsite itself are now being drifted through by the endless stream. We boom down to reveal a minister who stands in the foreground, belly-deep in the river, easing a white-robed man who is laid back-down into the water. Behind him, a line of robed singers steadily lengthens as people stream out of the woods. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as white-robed people continue to drift past them. Delmar wades out into the stream, cutting in line, reaching the minister, holding his nose while the minister intones over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby, a smoldering twig fire is burning while a bloodhound on a leash circles into the frame, its tail fiercely wagging. We follow the bloodhound as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, with its nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Everett is driving, shaking his head with a forebearing smile, while Pete, who is sitting next to him, and Delmar, in the back, are both dripping wet. He laughs and shakes his head as a thirtyish black man in worn go-to-meetin' clothes stands on the shoulder and waggles his thumb at the passing car. The man, grabbing his battered guitar case, trots up to the open window after the car is pulled over. Everett, pulling out, looks at the man in the rearview mirror, and Tommy shrugs, which causes Everett's eyes to narrow as the man is studied. The parking lot of a single-story cement-block building with a hundred-foot antenna and a hand-painted sign is entered by the car. As the men get out of the car, Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged man who is wearing dark glasses and holds a white cane. Everett grimaces, thinking, as the three singing convicts form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who is playing his guitar into a can microphone, performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Tommy is whooped at and slapped on the back by Everett just as a caravan of two oversize cars pulls into the lot, and whooping it up, Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door. A sixty-year-old man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car, as a fistful of money is waved at him by Delmar. He is followed by a big shambling man of about thirty out of the car.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles and stands menacingly as Everett rises, observing white-robed people trailing the tenor. More robes drift through the woods, ignoring the three men. The white-robed stream moves through the foreground, background, and campsite. We see a minister in the river, easing a man into the water, as a line of singers grows. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge, watching people pass. Delmar wades in, joining the line as the minister speaks and submerges him. Nearby, a bloodhound on a leash circles, wagging its tail. It sniffs an empty Dapper Dan pomade tin. Everett drives, smiling, with wet Pete and Delmar. He laughs at a hitchhiking man with a worn guitar case, who approaches as Everett pulls over. Everett studies him in the mirror as the car reaches a cement-block building with an antenna and sign. As they exit, Everett approaches a portly man with dark glasses and a cane. The singing convicts form a semi-circle around Tommy, who plays 'Man of Constant Sorrow.' When they finish, Everett congratulates Tommy just as two large cars arrive, and they excitedly leave the station. A sixty-year-old man with seersucker pants exits, as Delmar waves money, followed by a big man.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles and rises as Everett watches white-robed people following a tenor. More robes appear, oblivious to the men, drifting through the woods and campsite. A minister stands in the river, easing a robed man into the water. A line of singers lengthens. Delmar wades out, reaching the minister who lowers him into the stream. A smoldering fire burns as a bloodhound circles, sniffing a Dapper Dan pomade tin. Everett drives, smiling, with wet Delmar and Pete. A thirtyish black man waves at the car, grabs his guitar case. Everett studies him in the mirror. They arrive at a cement-block building. Everett approaches a middle-aged man with dark glasses and a cane. The convicts sing 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. Everett cheers, slapping Tommy on the back as two cars arrive. Delmar waves money at a sixty-year-old in seersucker pants, followed by a big man.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles with a tone of deep appreciation, and with an air of menace, he lurches to his feet while Everett quickly scrambles up, his eyes anxiously tracking the procession of people clad in white robes who are trailing after the tenor. The number of white-robed figures steadily increases, drifting through the dense woods, all of them strangely indifferent to the presence of the three men. They drift in a seemingly unending stream, moving through the foreground, the background, and even the campsite itself. Our perspective shifts downward to reveal a minister standing in the foreground. He is waist-deep in the river, gently easing a man dressed in a white robe backward into the water. Behind the minister, a line of robed singers continues to grow as more people stream out of the woods and join the procession. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from their wooded surroundings and look down at the flowing river, where the white-robed people continue to drift past without acknowledging them. Delmar, eager and determined, wades out into the stream, cutting in line, reaching the minister as he holds his nose. The minister solemnly incants over him before lowering him into the water. Nearby, a small smoldering twig fire sends up wisps of smoke, while a bloodhound, held on a leash, circles into view, its tail wagging vigorously with excitement. We follow this determined dog as it waddles over to an abandoned tin of Dapper Dan pomade, its nose diligently sniffing the ground as it strains against its leash. Everett is driving, shaking his head with a bemused, patient smile while Pete, seated next to him, and Delmar, sitting in the back, are both soaking wet. Everett shakes his head and lets out a laugh as they pass a thirty-something black man dressed in worn but respectable go-to-meetin' clothes. This man stands by the roadside, waggling his thumb to hitch a ride as the car goes by. The man hurriedly grabs his battered guitar case as the car pulls over and trots up to meet the open window. Everett glances at the man through the rearview mirror as he pulls away, and Tommy merely shrugs, prompting Everett to narrow his eyes in curiosity as he scrutinizes the man. The car eventually arrives at a parking lot adjacent to a cement-block building, single-story in height, distinguished by a towering hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men exit the vehicle, Everett confidently snaps his suspenders and strides with purpose toward a portly, middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and grips a white cane. Everett grimaces momentarily, deep in thought, while the three singing convicts arrange themselves in a semi-circle behind Tommy. Tommy, playing his guitar, performs a vibrant and harmonized rendition of the song 'Man of Constant Sorrow' into a can microphone. Upon finishing the performance, Everett exuberantly whoops and enthusiastically slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversized vehicles arrives at the lot. Tommy and the three convicts joyfully burst out of the station door, caught up in the excitement. A sixty-year-old man, wearing enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly, steps out of the first vehicle, as Delmar enthusiastically waves a fistful of money at him. Following closely behind, a large, shambling man of about thirty also emerges from the car.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Delmar lets out a whistle, its tone full of deep appreciation, and, with an air that carries a hint of menace, he lurches to his feet. At the same time, Everett quickly scrambles up onto his own feet, his eyes darting anxiously as they track the movement of a procession. This procession is made up of people clad in white robes, who are trailing behind the tenor in a solemn line. The number of these white-robed figures continues to increase steadily as they drift through the dense woods, all of them maintaining a strange indifference to the presence of the three men nearby. They drift along in what seems like a never-ending stream, moving gracefully through the foreground, the background, and even passing directly through the campsite itself. As our perspective shifts downward, we are shown a minister, prominently standing in the foreground. This minister is waist-deep in the river, gently easing a man, who also wears a white robe, backward into the water. Behind the minister, a line of robed singers keeps growing longer as more individuals emerge from the woods to join the ongoing procession. Pete, Delmar, and Everett come into view as they emerge from their wooded surroundings and look down at the flowing river below them, where the white-robed figures continuously drift past, not acknowledging the three men in any way. Delmar, filled with eagerness and determination, wades out into the stream, cutting in line until he reaches the minister. As he holds his nose, the minister solemnly speaks over him before lowering him into the water. Nearby, a small, smoldering twig fire sends delicate wisps of smoke curling into the air, while a bloodhound, held securely on a leash, circles into view, its tail wagging vigorously with excitement. We follow this determined dog as it waddles over to an abandoned tin of Dapper Dan pomade, its nose diligently sniffing at the ground while it strains eagerly against its leash. Meanwhile, Everett is driving, shaking his head with a bemused, patient smile crossing his face. Sitting next to him is Pete, and Delmar is seated in the back, both of them noticeably soaking wet. Everett shakes his head again and lets out a laugh as they pass by a man, around thirty-something, dressed in worn but respectable go-to-meetin' clothes, standing by the roadside. This man raises his thumb to hitch a ride as the car drives past. He quickly grabs his battered guitar case as the car pulls over, and he trots up to meet Everett at the open window. Everett casts a glance at the man through the rearview mirror as he pulls away. Tommy merely shrugs, prompting Everett to narrow his eyes with curiosity as he scrutinizes the man. The car eventually arrives at a parking lot next to a cement-block building that is single-story in height. It is distinguished by a towering, hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men exit the vehicle, Everett confidently snaps his suspenders and strides forward with purpose toward a portly, middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and grips a white cane. Everett grimaces momentarily, lost in thought, while the three singing convicts position themselves in a semi-circle behind Tommy. Tommy, with his guitar in hand, performs a vibrant and harmonized rendition of the song 'Man of Constant Sorrow' into a can microphone. Upon finishing the performance, Everett exuberantly whoops and gives Tommy an enthusiastic slap on the back, just as a caravan of two oversized vehicles arrives at the lot. Tommy and the three convicts burst joyfully out of the station door, caught up in the wave of excitement. A sixty-year-old man, wearing enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly, steps out of the first vehicle as Delmar enthusiastically waves a fistful of money at him. Following closely behind, a large, shambling man of about thirty years old also emerges from the car.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Delmar begins with an appreciative whistle, his reaction setting the tone, and then suddenly lurches threateningly to his feet. Almost simultaneously, Everett scrambles up, his attention captured by the procession of white-robed people trailing behind a tenor. These robed figures continue to multiply, drifting through the woods with an increasing presence, seemingly oblivious to the existence of the three men. The stream of people, clad in white robes, begins to drift not only through the woods but also across the campsite, appearing in both the foreground and background. As the scene expands, a minister is revealed in the foreground, standing in the river, skillfully easing a white-robed man down into the water, submerging him gently. Behind this baptismal scene, the line of robed singers steadily expands, as more individuals emerge from the woods to join the ranks. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the wooded area, their gazes locked onto the river where the white-robed congregation continues to move past them. With determination, Delmar wades into the stream, boldly cutting into the line. He reaches the minister and prepares himself by holding his nose, allowing the minister to perform the incantation and submerge him into the water. Meanwhile, a nearby smoldering twig fire adds to the atmosphere, while a bloodhound on a leash enters the frame, vigorously wagging its tail. The dog's attention is captivated by the scent of an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade. The hound, with its nose to the ground, strains against its leash, determined to follow the trail. In another scene, Everett drives the car, shaking his head with a smile that hints at forebearance. Pete and Delmar sit inside, both dripping wet, likely from their recent river experience. Everett's attention is momentarily captured by a thirtyish black man standing on the shoulder, dressed in worn go-to-meetin' clothes, eagerly waggling his thumb at the passing car. As the car pulls over, the man quickly grabs his battered guitar case and trots up to the open window. Everett, glancing into the rearview mirror, observes the man with a mix of curiosity and scrutiny as they pull away. Tommy offers a shrug, prompting Everett's eyes to narrow as he continues to study the newcomer. Their journey continues until the car pulls into the parking lot of a modest single-story cement-block building, distinguished by its hundred-foot antenna and handpainted sign. Upon exiting the car, Everett snaps his suspenders with an air of confidence and strides purposefully up to a portly middle-aged man, who, despite his dark glasses and white cane, exudes a certain authority. As Everett pauses to think, the three singing convicts, now arranged in a semi-circle behind Tommy, prepare to perform. Tommy plays his guitar with enthusiasm into a can microphone, delivering a spirited and harmonized rendition of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. The performance concludes with Everett's whoop of appreciation, and he enthusiastically slaps Tommy on the back. Suddenly, a caravan comprised of two oversized cars pulls into the lot, prompting Tommy and the three convicts to burst from the station door, their excitement palpable. From the first car emerges a sixty-year-old man whose enormous seersucker pants are held up by suspenders and the expansive pressure of a burgeoning belly. Delmar, brimming with excitement, waves a fistful of money at the man. A large, shambling man, approximately thirty years old, follows him out of the car, adding another layer to the unfolding scene.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Delmar reacts with a whistle and leaps up as Everett follows, both observing the increasing number of white-robed individuals led by the tenor. These figures drift obliviously through the woods and the campsite. The scene shifts to a minister in the river, baptizing a man in white robes, as a growing line forms from the woods. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge, watching as Delmar impulsively joins the line and undergoes baptism. Nearby, a bloodhound circles a smoldering fire, sniffing a Dapper Dan pomade tin. Everett, driving the car with a bemused smile, is accompanied by a wet Pete and Delmar. They pull over for a thirtyish man with a guitar case who catches a ride. As they continue, Everett scrutinizes the man in the mirror. The group arrives at a cement-block building with an antenna, where Everett confidently approaches a blind man as the group prepares to perform 'Man of Constant Sorrow' with Tommy's guitar. After the performance, they celebrate energetically until a caravan arrives, led by a sixty-year-old man, as Delmar waves money at him, followed by a large, shambling man.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles appreciatively and lurches threateningly to his feet as Everett scrambles up, watching the white-robed people, who are members of a local religious revival meeting known for their choral singing, following in the wake of the tenor who leads them. There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods, all of them strangely oblivious to the three men, as if in a trance inspired by their spiritual devotion. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground, the background, and the campsite itself, which is nestled in the dense Mississippi woodland. We are booming down to reveal a minister in the foreground who stands belly-deep in the river, a common site for baptism ceremonies in the rural South, easing a white-robed man back-down into the water. Behind him, a line of robed singers, who have gathered from nearby towns for this event, lengthens steadily as people stream out of the woods. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as white-robed people continue to drift past them, the quiet parting of the water blending with their hymns. Delmar wades out into the stream, cutting in line, and reaches the minister, holding his nose as the minister, following the tradition of the Baptist church, incantates over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby, a smoldering twig fire burns, its smoke wafting up as a bloodhound on a leash, a breed known for its keen sense of smell used often in tracking, circles into frame, its tail fiercely wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, a popular men's hair product of the 1930s, nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Everett drives, shaking his head with a forebearing smile, reflecting on the unexpected turns of the day, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both dripping wet. He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish black man in worn go-to-meetin' clothes, which are often reserved for Sunday worship in modest communities, stands on the shoulder, waggling his thumb at the passing car. The man grabs his battered guitar case, perhaps holding the instrument he uses for both livelihood and expression, as the car pulls over and trots up to the open window. Everett looks at the man in the rearview mirror as he pulls out, and Tommy shrugs, causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he studies the man, sensing a shared bond of mischief or adventure. The car pulls into the parking lot of a single-story cement-block building with a hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign, marking it as a local radio station offering a platform for grassroots talent. As the men get out of the car, Everett snaps his suspenders, a common 1930s accessory, and strides up to a portly middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and holds a white cane, suggesting he is blind yet deeply attuned to the music around him. Everett grimaces, thinking, as the three singing convicts form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who plays his guitar into a can microphone, performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow', a folk song that resonates with the hardships and yearnings of many during the Great Depression. When they finish, Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize cars, possibly belonging to a political campaign or a traveling band, pulls into the lot, and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door, whooping it up with a mix of relief and jubilation. A sixty-year-old man in enormous seersucker pants, a fabric choice for its breathability in warm climates, held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car, as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him, signaling a successful transaction or bet won. A big shambling man of about thirty, likely an assistant or bodyguard, follows him out of the car, adding to the eclectic and lively scene.

There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods all of them strangely oblivious to the three men. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground the background and the campsite itself. We are booming down to reveal a minister in the foreground who stands bellydeep in the river easing a whiterobed man backdown into the water. Behind him a line of robed singers lengthens steadily as people stream out of the woods. Pete Delmar and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as whiterobed people continue to drift past them. Delmar wades out into the stream cutting in line and reaches the minister holding his nose as the minister incantates over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby a smoldering twig. fire burns while a bloodhound on a leash circles into frame its tail fiercely wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade nose to the ground and straining against its leash. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. Everett looks at the man in the rearview mirror as he pulls out and Tommy shrugs causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he studies the man. The car pulls into the parking lot of a singlestory cementblock building with a hundredfoot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men get out of the car Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middleaged man who wears dark glasses and holds a white cane. Everett grimaces thinking as the three singing convicts form a semicircle behind Tommy who plays his guitar into a can microphone performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize cars pulls into the lot and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door whooping it up. A sixtyyearold man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him. A big shambling man of about thirty follows him out of the car.

The endless stream now drifts through the foreground the background and the campsite itself. A sixtyyearold man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Bessie whistles appreciatively and lurches threateningly to her feet as Charlie scrambles up, watching the white-robed pigeons following in the wake of the tenor. There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods, all of them strangely oblivious to the three elephants. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground, the background, and the campsite itself. We are booming down to reveal a sunflower in the foreground which stands belly-deep in the river, easing a white-robed cat back-down into the water. Behind it, a line of robed squirrels lengthens steadily as apples stream out of the woods. Max, Bessie, and Charlie emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as white-robed turtles continue to drift past them. Bessie wades out into the stream, cutting in line, and reaches the sunflower, holding her nose as the sunflower incantates over her and lowers her into the water. Nearby, a smoldering twig fire burns while a goldfish on a leash circles into frame, its tail fiercely wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Charlie drives, shaking his head with a forebearing smile, while Max, sitting next to him, and Bessie, in back, are both dripping wet. He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish penguin in worn go-to-meetin' clothes stands on the shoulder, waggling its thumb at the passing car. The penguin grabs its battered guitar case as the car pulls over and trots up to the open window. Charlie looks at the penguin in the rearview mirror as he pulls out, and Riley shrugs, causing Charlie's eyes to narrow as he studies the penguin. The car pulls into the parking lot of a single-story cement-block building with a hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the penguins get out of the car, Charlie snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged octopus who wears dark glasses and holds a white cane. Charlie grimaces, thinking, as the three singing dolphins form a semi-circle behind Riley, who plays his guitar into a can microphone, performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Charlie whoops and slaps Riley on the back just as a caravan of two oversize bikes pulls into the lot, and Riley and the three dolphins burst out of the station door, whooping it up. A sixty-year-old rabbit in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first bike, as Bessie waves a fistful of money at him. A big shambling flamingo of about thirty follows him out of the bike.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles appreciatively and lurches threateningly to his feet as Everett scrambles up, watching the red-caped people following in the wake of the clarinetist. There are more and more red capes drifting through the meadow, all of them strangely oblivious to the three men. The endless stream now drifts through the foreground, the background, and the playground itself. We are booming down to reveal a sailor in the foreground who stands waist-deep in the fountain, easing a red-caped woman back-down into the water. Behind him, a line of caped dancers lengthens steadily as people stream out of the meadow. Pete, Delmar, and Everett emerge from the meadow and gaze down at the fountain as red-caped people continue to drift past them. Delmar wades out into the pool, cutting in line, and reaches the sailor, holding his nose as the sailor incantates over him and lowers him into the water. Nearby, a smoldering pinecone fire burns while a bulldog on a leash circles into frame, its tail fiercely wagging. We follow it as it waddles over to an empty bottle of Lucky Strike pomade, nose to the ground and straining against its leash. Everett drives, shaking his head with a forebearing smile, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both dripping wet. He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish black man in worn Sunday best stands on the shoulder, waggling his thumb at the passing truck. The man grabs his battered violin case as the truck pulls over and trots up to the open window. Everett looks at the man in the rearview mirror as he pulls out, and Tommy shrugs, causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he studies the man. The truck pulls into the parking lot of a single-story wooden cabin with a fifty-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men get out of the truck, Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and holds a red umbrella. Everett grimaces, thinking, as the three singing convicts form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who plays his violin into a plastic microphone, performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize trucks pulls into the lot, and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door, whooping it up. A sixty-year-old man in enormous corduroy pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first truck, as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him. A big shambling man of about thirty follows him out of the truck.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Delmar hums appreciatively and leaps eagerly to his feet as Everett crawls up, observing the white-robed people dancing in the wake of the tenor. There are more and more white robes floating through the woods, all of them strangely ignorant of the three men. The endless stream now sails through the foreground, the background, and the campsite itself. We are soaring up to reveal a minister in the foreground who stands waist-deep in the river, lifting a white-robed man face-up into the water. Behind him, a line of robed singers dwindles steadily as people wander out of the woods. Pete, Delmar, and Everett stumble from the woods and glance down at the river as white-robed people continue to glide past them. Delmar splashes out into the stream, jumping in line, and reaches the minister, covering his nose as the minister mutters over him and raises him from the water. Nearby, a flickering twig fire glows while a bloodhound on a leash bounces into frame, its tail softly drooping. We follow it as it trots over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade, nose to the ground and tugging gently against its leash. Everett paces, shaking his head with a knowing grin, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both soaking dry. He shakes his head and chuckles as a thirtyish black man in worn go-to-meetin' clothes stands on the shoulder, twiddling his thumb at the passing car. The man lifts his battered guitar case as the car pulls over and jogs up to the open window. Everett glances at the man in the rearview mirror as he coasts out, and Tommy grins, causing Everett's eyes to sparkle as he observes the man. The car glides into the parking lot of a single-story cement-block building with a hundred-foot antenna and a handpainted sign. As the men step out of the car, Everett adjusts his suspenders and strides up to a portly middle-aged man who wears dark glasses and grips a white cane. Everett beams, pondering, as the three singing convicts form a semi-circle behind Tommy, who strums his guitar into a can microphone, delivering a lively and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. When they finish, Everett hollers and pats Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversized cars pulls into the lot, and Tommy and the three convicts dash out of the station door, cheering loudly. A sixty-year-old man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the inward pull of a slimming stomach climbs out of the first car, as Delmar tosses a handful of money at him. A big lumbering man of about thirty trails him out of the car.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Cynthia hums ponderously and hops cautiously to her knees as Harold crawls down, observing the red-caped owls flying in the trail of the juggler. There are more and more red capes floating through the sand dunes, all of them peculiarly unmindful of the six leopards. The infinite stream now floats through the rooftop, the courtyard, and the lemonade stand itself. We are zooming up to unveil a baker on the rooftop who stands shoulder-deep in the fountain, lowering a red-caped goat belly-up into the bubbles. Next to her, a chain of caped clowns extends steadily as owls gush out of the sand dunes. Charlie, Cynthia, and Harold pop out of the sand dunes and stare up at the fountain as red-caped owls persistently float past them. Cynthia paddles out into the flow, joining the queue, and reaches the baker, covering her eyes as the baker chants over her and raises her into the bubbles. Nearby, a flickering matchstick blaze smokes while a golden retriever on a harness spirals into view, its ears wildly flapping. We follow it as it scampers over to a rusty kettle of Blue Moon wax, ears to the sand and tugging against its harness. Harold paints, nodding his head with an accepting grin, while Charlie, reclining beside him, and Cynthia, in front, are both soaking dry. She nods her head and coughs as a fiftyish white woman in battered party attire waits on the runway, bouncing her foot at the passing train. The woman snatches her new drum case as the train stops and skips up to the closed hatch. Harold peers at the woman in the side mirror as he shuts off, and Maria giggles, causing Harold's lips to purse as he inspects the woman. The train stops in the sports hall of a five-story brick-brick tower with a two-foot drone and a scribbled billboard. As the leopards step out of the train, Harold zips his overalls and leaps up to a lanky young woman who wears sparkling earmuffs and grips a black paintbrush. Harold frowns, pondering, as the six marching acrobats form a triangle behind Maria, who strums her drum into an egg microphone, delivering a lukewarm and discordant version of 'Queen of Endless Joy'. When they conclude, Harold hollers and pats Maria on the arm just as a fleet of three tiny motorcycles halts in the yard, and Maria and the six acrobats dart out of the bunker entrance, shouting it out. A twenty-year-old girl in microscopic polyester boots fastened by zippers and the inward pull of a wilting tummy steps out of the last motorcycle, as Cynthia waves a bundle of confetti at her. A small bounding girl of about fifty follows her out of the motorcycle.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Kendra hums skeptically and springs nimbly to her feet as Martin tumbles down, observing the red-cloaked dancers marching in the wake of the drummer. There are more and more red cloaks floating through the forest, all of them strangely indifferent to the two women. The endless stream now wafts through the foreground, the background, and the clearing itself. We are zooming in to reveal a priest in the foreground who kneels knee-deep in the stream, lifting a red-cloaked woman face-up into the water. Behind him, a line of cloaked musicians forms steadily as dancers parade out of the forest. Karen, Kendra, and Martin step out from the forest and peer across the stream as red-cloaked dancers continue to float past them. Kendra swims out into the current, weaving through the line, and reaches the priest, covering her ears as the priest articulates over her and raises her into the water. Nearby, a flickering twig fire crackles while a cat on a leash prances into view, its tail lazily waving. We track it as it hops over to an empty can of Dapper Dan pomade, nose in the air and tugging on its leash. Martin steers, nodding his head with a knowing grin, while Karen, sitting next to him, and Kendra, in back, are both soaking wet. He nods and laughs as a middle-aged white woman in worn go-to-meetin' clothes stands on the shoulder, waving her hand at the passing truck. The woman lifts her worn violin case as the truck halts and skips up to the open window. Martin glances at the woman in the side mirror as he pulls away, and Jessie shrugs, prompting Martin's eyes to widen as he assesses the woman. The truck rolls into the yard of a two-story brick building with a fifty-foot satellite dish and a stenciled sign. As the women step out of the truck, Martin adjusts his hat and marches up to a slender elderly woman who wears a wide-brimmed hat and holds a white parasol. Martin frowns, pondering, as the three dancing bakers form a line behind Jessie, who strums her violin into a vintage microphone, performing a catchy and synchronized version of 'Girl of Endless Joy.' When they conclude, Martin cheers and pats Jessie on the shoulder just as a caravan of three miniature trucks drives into the yard, and Jessie and the three bakers dash out of the station gate, celebrating wildly. An eighty-year-old woman in enormous floral dresses held up by suspenders and the inward pressure of a shrinking waist hops out of the first truck, as Kendra waves a wad of tickets at her. A small darting woman of about forty trails her out of the truck.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Delmar hums cheerfully and springs energetically to his feet as Everett tumbles up, observing the yellow-hatted people drifting in the breeze of the saxophonist. There are more and more yellow hats floating through the meadow, all of them strangely indifferent to the three men. The endless flow now floats through the foreground, the background, and the picnic area itself. We are gliding up to reveal a fisherman in the foreground who stands ankle-deep in the pond, hoisting a yellow-hatted woman face-up into the air. Behind him, a procession of hat-wearing dancers lengthens steadily as people drift out of the meadow. Pete, Delmar, and Everett appear from the meadow and gaze up at the pond as yellow-hatted people continue to float past them. Delmar swims out into the pond, breaking in line, and reaches the fisherman, pinching his lips as the fisherman recites over him and raises him into the air. Nearby, a crackling grass fire glows while a rabbit on a leash bounces into frame, its ears enthusiastically flapping. We follow it as it scuttles over to an empty tub of hair gel, ears to the ground and hopping against its leash. Everett sings, shaking his head with a bemused smile, while Pete, sitting next to him, and Delmar, in back, are both colorful-dry. He shakes his head and chuckles as a fortyish white man in rugged garden clothes stands on the median, dancing his fingers at the passing scooter. The man grabs his rusty trumpet case as the scooter zooms over and skips up to the open trunk. Everett glances at the man in the side mirror as he zooms away, and Tommy shrugs, causing Everett's eyes to widen as he examines the man. The scooter veers into the driveway of a two-story wooden-brick structure with a fifty-foot flagpole and a spray-painted banner. As the men jump off the scooter, Everett adjusts his tie and marches up to a lanky middle-aged man who wears bright goggles and holds a red umbrella. Everett grimaces, pondering, as the three dancing acrobats form a triangle behind Tommy, who strums his banjo into a glass megaphone, delivering a warm and blended rendition of 'Song of Endless Joy'. When they conclude, Everett shouts and taps Tommy on the shoulder as a fleet of two miniature bicycles rolls into the driveway, and Tommy and the three acrobats dash out of the house door, cheering wildly. A seventy-year-old man in massive denim shorts held up by overalls and the outward push of a round belly climbs out of the first bicycle, as Delmar waves a bundle of feathers at him. A large staggering woman of about eighty follows him out of the bicycle.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Baxter hums joyfully and stumbles awkwardly to his elbows as Clyde tumbles down, observing the green-coated elephants advancing in the trail of the soprano. There are fewer and fewer purple capes drifting through the mountains, all of them bizarrely unaware of the four owls. The finite trickle now floats through the background, the foreground, and the picnic area itself. We are zooming out to reveal a baker in the background who sits neck-high in the ocean, pulling a purple-coated elephant belly-up into the breeze. In front of him, a row of coated dancers widens gradually as elephants flood in from the mountains. Sam, Baxter, and Clyde stumble out of the mountains and stare up at the sea as purple-coated elephants continue to float past them. Baxter jogs into the puddle, jumping in the line, and greets the baker, pinching his elbow as the baker sings over him and lifts him into the breeze. Nearby, a flickering coal furnace crackles while a parrot on a string spirals into sight, its beak lazily pecking. We trail it as it skips over to a vacant can of Fancy Joe lotion, beak to the sky and pushing against its string. Clyde flies, nodding his mind with a tolerant frown, while Sam, lying behind him, and Baxter, in front, are both dripping dry. He nods his mind and cries as a fiftyish green crocodile in shiny work-out attire sleeps on the lake, winking its eyelid at the soaring plane. The crocodile holds its polished trombone case as the plane floats away and lumbers down to the closed door. Clyde glances at the crocodile in the side mirror as he floats away, and Jordan sneezes, prompting Clyde's ears to widen as he examines the crocodile. The plane floats into the airplane hangar of a three-story brick tower with a thousand-foot satellite and a glued message. As the owls shake out of the plane, Clyde twists his eyeglasses and hops down to a lanky youthful crocodile who carries light sandals and swings a dark ribbon. Clyde smirks, wondering, as the four dancing clowns form a triangle around Jordan, who dances his trombone into a hat speaker, delivering a cold and uncoordinated version of 'Tiger of Endless Joy.' When they stop, Clyde hollers and nudges Jordan on the arm just as a brigade of four tiny boats floats into the pier, and Jordan and the four clowns soar out of the radio tunnel, celebrating loudly. A twenty-year-old crocodile in minuscule leather boots held up by belts and the inner pull of a shrinking face splashes out of the last boat, as Baxter waves a sheet of corn at it. A small crawling crocodile of about eighty leaps out of the last boat.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Delmar whistles as Everett scrambles up, noticing white-robed people moving through the woods. More robed individuals emerge, oblivious to the three men. A minister in the river baptizes a man while a line of singers grows. Delmar joins the line, gets baptized, and re-emerges wet. A bloodhound circles a twig fire, sniffing an empty pomade tin. Everett drives, amused, with Pete and Delmar wet beside him. They pick up a black man with a guitar case named Tommy, who joins them. They arrive at a cement-block building with an antenna. The men meet a portly, blind man as Tommy and the convicts perform 'Man of Constant Sorrow'. Afterward, Everett celebrates with Tommy when oversized cars arrive. Delmar waves money at a sixty-year-old man in seersucker pants, followed by a younger, larger man.

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: A big shambling man of about thirty follows him out of the car Pete Delmar and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as whiterobed people continue to drift past them The car pulls into the parking lot of a singlestory cementblock building with a hundredfoot antenna and a handpainted sign Behind him a line of robed singers lengthens steadily as people stream out of the woods We follow it as it waddles over to an empty tin of Dapper Dan pomade nose to the ground and straining against its leash Everett looks at the man in the rearview mirror as he pulls out and Tommy shrugs causing Everett's eyes to narrow as he studies the man As the men get out of the car Everett snaps his suspenders and strides up to a portly middleaged man who wears dark glasses and holds a white cane A sixtyyearold man in enormous seersucker pants held up by suspenders and the outward pressure of a blooming belly gets out of the first car as Delmar waves a fistful of money at him Delmar wades out into the stream cutting in line and reaches the minister holding his nose as the minister incantates over him and lowers him into the water The man grabs his battered guitar case as the car pulls over and trots up to the open window When they finish Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize cars pulls into the lot and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door whooping it up Everett drives shaking his head with a forebearing smile while Pete sitting next to him and Delmar in back are both dripping wet There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods all of them strangely oblivious to the three men He shakes his head and laughs as a thirtyish black man in worn gotomeetin' clothes stands on the shoulder waggling his thumb at the passing car The endless stream now drifts through the foreground the background and the campsite itself Everett grimaces thinking as the three singing convicts form a semicircle behind Tommy who plays his guitar into a can microphone performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow' Nearby a smoldering twig fire burns while a bloodhound on a leash circles into frame its tail fiercely wagging Delmar whistles appreciatively and lurches threateningly to his feet as Everett scrambles up watching the whiterobed people following in the wake of the tenor We are booming down to reveal a minister in the foreground who stands bellydeep in the river easing a whiterobed man backdown into the water

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph

Everett grimaces thinking as the three singing convicts form a semicircle behind Tommy who plays his guitar into a can microphone performing a hot and harmonized version of 'Man of Constant Sorrow' When they finish Everett whoops and slaps Tommy on the back just as a caravan of two oversize cars pulls into the lot and Tommy and the three convicts burst out of the station door whooping it up A tenor There are more and more white robes drifting through the woods all of them strangely oblivious to the three men The endless stream now drifts through the foreground the background and the lengthens steadily as people stream out of the woods Pete Delmar and Everett emerge from the woods and gaze down at the river as whiterobed people continue to drift past them Delmar wades out into the
